dialogue: Which is it to-day? /newquote morphine or cocaine?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He raised his eyes languidly from the old black-letter volume which he had opened.  /newquote  he said,
dialogue: It is cocaine, /newquote a seven-per-cent. solution. Would you care to try it?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, indeed, /newquote My constitution has not got over the Afghan campaign yet. I cannot afford to throw any extra strain upon it.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He smiled at my vehemence.  /newquote  he said.
dialogue: Perhaps you are right, Watson, /newquote I suppose that its influence is physically a bad one. I find it, however, so transcendently stimulating and clarifying to the mind that its secondary action is a matter of small moment.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But consider! /newquote Count the cost! Your brain may, as you say, be roused and excited, but it is a pathological and morbid process, which involves increased tissue-change and may at last leave a permanent weakness. You know, too, what a black reaction comes upon you. Surely the game is hardly worth the candle. Why should you, for a mere passing pleasure, risk the loss of those great powers with which you have been endowed? Remember that I speak not only as one comrade to another, but as a medical man to one for whose constitution he is to some extent answerable.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: My mind, /newquote rebels at stagnation. Give me problems, give me work, give me the most abstruse cryptogram or the most intricate analysis, and I am in my own proper atmosphere. I can dispense then with artificial stimulants. But I abhor the dull routine of existence. I crave for mental exaltation. That is why I have chosen my own particular profession, or rather created it, for I am the only one in the world.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The only unofficial detective?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The only unofficial consulting detective, /newquote I am the last and highest court of appeal in detection. When Gregson or Lestrade or Athelney Jones are out of their depths which, by the way, is their normal state the matter is laid before me. I examine the data, as an expert, and pronounce a specialist s opinion. I claim no credit in such cases. My name figures in no newspaper. The work itself, the pleasure of finding a field for my peculiar powers, is my highest reward. But you have yourself had some experience of my methods of work in the Jefferson Hope case.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, indeed, /newquote I was never so struck by anything in my life. I even embodied it in a small brochure with the somewhat fantastic title of  A Study in Scarlet.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He shook his head sadly.  /newquote  said he.
dialogue: I glanced over it, /newquote Honestly, I cannot congratulate you upon it. Detection is, or ought to be, an exact science, and should be treated in the same cold and unemotional manner. You have attempted to tinge it with romanticism, which produces much the same effect as if you worked a love-story or an elopement into the fifth proposition of Euclid.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But the romance was there, /newquote I could not tamper with the facts.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Some facts should be suppressed, or at least a just sense of proportion should be observed in treating them. The only point in the case which deserved mention was the curious analytical reasoning from effects to causes by which I succeeded in unraveling it.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Holmes, after a while, filling up his old brier-root pipe.  /newquote  He tossed over, as he spoke, a crumpled sheet of foreign notepaper. I glanced my eyes down it, catching a profusion of notes of admiration, with stray  /newquote   /newquote  and  /newquote  all testifying to the ardent admiration of the Frenchman.
dialogue: My practice has extended recently to the Continent, /newquote I was consulted last week by Fran ois Le Villard, who, as you probably know, has come rather to the front lately in the French detective service. He has all the Celtic power of quick intuition, but he is deficient in the wide range of exact knowledge which is essential to the higher developments of his art. The case was concerned with a will, and possessed some features of interest. I was able to refer him to two parallel cases, the one at Riga in 1857, and the other at St. Louis in 1871, which have suggested to him the true solution. Here is the letter which I had this morning acknowledging my assistance. /newquote magnifiques, /newquote coup-de-ma tres, /newquote tours-de-force,
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: He speaks as a pupil to his master,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Oh, he rates my assistance too highly, /newquote He has considerable gifts himself. He possesses two out of the three qualities necessary for the ideal detective. He has the power of observation and that of deduction. He is only wanting in knowledge; and that may come in time. He is now translating my small works into French.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Your works?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Oh, didn t you know? /newquote Yes, I have been guilty of several monographs. They are all upon technical subjects. Here, for example, is one  Upon the Distinction between the Ashes of the Various Tobaccoes.  In it I enumerate a hundred and forty forms of cigar-, cigarette-, and pipe-tobacco, with coloured plates illustrating the difference in the ash. It is a point which is continually turning up in criminal trials, and which is sometimes of supreme importance as a clue. If you can say definitely, for example, that some murder has been done by a man who was smoking an Indian lunkah, it obviously narrows your field of search. To the trained eye there is as much difference between the black ash of a Trichinopoly and the white fluff of bird s-eye as there is between a cabbage and a potato.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You have an extraordinary genius for minuti ,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I appreciate their importance. Here is my monograph upon the tracing of footsteps, with some remarks upon the uses of plaster of Paris as a preserver of impresses. Here, too, is a curious little work upon the influence of a trade upon the form of the hand, with lithotypes of the hands of slaters, sailors, corkcutters, compositors, weavers, and diamond-polishers. That is a matter of great practical interest to the scientific detective, especially in cases of unclaimed bodies, or in discovering the antecedents of criminals. But I weary you with my hobby.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Not at all, /newquote It is of the greatest interest to me, especially since I have had the opportunity of observing your practical application of it. But you spoke just now of observation and deduction. Surely the one to some extent implies the other.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he answered, leaning back luxuriously in his arm-chair, and sending up thick blue wreaths from his pipe.
dialogue: Why, hardly, /newquote For example, observation shows me that you have been to the Wigmore Street Post-Office this morning, but deduction lets me know that when there you dispatched a telegram.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Right! /newquote Right on both points! But I confess that I don t see how you arrived at it. It was a sudden impulse upon my part, and I have mentioned it to no one.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he remarked, chuckling at my surprise,
dialogue: It is simplicity itself, /newquote so absurdly simple that an explanation is superfluous; and yet it may serve to define the limits of observation and of deduction. Observation tells me that you have a little reddish mould adhering to your instep. Just opposite the Seymour Street Office they have taken up the pavement and thrown up some earth which lies in such a way that it is difficult to avoid treading in it in entering. The earth is of this peculiar reddish tint which is found, as far as I know, nowhere else in the neighbourhood. So much is observation. The rest is deduction.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: How, then, did you deduce the telegram?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Why, of course I knew that you had not written a letter, since I sat opposite to you all morning. I see also in your open desk there that you have a sheet of stamps and a thick bundle of post-cards. What could you go into the post-office for, then, but to send a wire? Eliminate all other factors, and the one which remains must be the truth.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I replied, after a little thought.
dialogue: In this case it certainly is so, /newquote The thing, however, is, as you say, of the simplest. Would you think me impertinent if I were to put your theories to a more severe test?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: On the contrary, /newquote it would prevent me from taking a second dose of cocaine. I should be delighted to look into any problem which you might submit to me.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I have heard you say that it is difficult for a man to have any object in daily use without leaving the impress of his individuality upon it in such a way that a trained observer might read it. Now, I have here a watch which has recently come into my possession. Would you have the kindness to let me have an opinion upon the character or habits of the late owner?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: There are hardly any data, /newquote The watch has been recently cleaned, which robs me of my most suggestive facts.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I answered.  /newquote  In my heart I accused my companion of putting forward a most lame and impotent excuse to cover his failure. What data could he expect from an uncleaned watch?
dialogue: You are right, /newquote It was cleaned before being sent to me.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he observed, staring up at the ceiling with dreamy, lack-lustre eyes.
dialogue: Though unsatisfactory, my research has not been entirely barren, /newquote Subject to your correction, I should judge that the watch belonged to your elder brother, who inherited it from your father.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: That you gather, no doubt, from the H. W. upon the back?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Quite so. The W. suggests your own name. The date of the watch is nearly fifty years back, and the initials are as old as the watch: so it was made for the last generation. Jewelry usually descends to the eldest son, and he is most likely to have the same name as the father. Your father has, if I remember right, been dead many years. It has, therefore, been in the hands of your eldest brother.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Right, so far, /newquote Anything else?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: He was a man of untidy habits, very untidy and careless. He was left with good prospects, but he threw away his chances, lived for some time in poverty with occasional short intervals of prosperity, and finally, taking to drink, he died. That is all I can gather.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: This is unworthy of you, Holmes, /newquote I could not have believed that you would have descended to this. You have made inquires into the history of my unhappy brother, and you now pretend to deduce this knowledge in some fanciful way. You cannot expect me to believe that you have read all this from his old watch! It is unkind, and, to speak plainly, has a touch of charlatanism in it.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: My dear doctor, /newquote pray accept my apologies. Viewing the matter as an abstract problem, I had forgotten how personal and painful a thing it might be to you. I assure you, however, that I never even knew that you had a brother until you handed me the watch.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Then how in the name of all that is wonderful did you get these facts? They are absolutely correct in every particular.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Ah, that is good luck. I could only say what was the balance of probability. I did not at all expect to be so accurate.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But it was not mere guess-work?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, no: I never guess. It is a shocking habit, destructive to the logical faculty. What seems strange to you is only so because you do not follow my train of thought or observe the small facts upon which large inferences may depend. For example, I began by stating that your brother was careless. When you observe the lower part of that watch-case you notice that it is not only dinted in two places, but it is cut and marked all over from the habit of keeping other hard objects, such as coins or keys, in the same pocket. Surely it is no great feat to assume that a man who treats a fifty-guinea watch so cavalierly must be a careless man. Neither is it a very far-fetched inference that a man who inherits one article of such value is pretty well provided for in other respects.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is very customary for pawnbrokers in England, when they take a watch, to scratch the number of the ticket with a pin-point upon the inside of the case. It is more handy than a label, as there is no risk of the number being lost or transposed. There are no less than four such numbers visible to my lens on the inside of this case. Inference, that your brother was often at low water. Secondary inference, that he had occasional bursts of prosperity, or he could not have redeemed the pledge. Finally, I ask you to look at the inner plate, which contains the key-hole. Look at the thousands of scratches all round the hole, marks where the key has slipped. What sober man s key could have scored those grooves? But you will never see a drunkard s watch without them. He winds it at night, and he leaves these traces of his unsteady hand. Where is the mystery in all this?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is as clear as daylight, /newquote I regret the injustice which I did you. I should have had more faith in your marvellous faculty. May I ask whether you have any professional inquiry on foot at present?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: None. Hence the cocaine. I cannot live without brain-work. What else is there to live for? Stand at the window here. Was ever such a dreary, dismal, unprofitable world? See how the yellow fog swirls down the street and drifts across the dun-coloured houses. What could be more hopelessly prosaic and material? What is the use of having powers, doctor, when one has no field upon which to exert them? Crime is commonplace, existence is commonplace, and no qualities save those which are commonplace have any function upon earth.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I exclaimed, turning to my companion.
dialogue: What a very attractive woman!
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He had lit his pipe again, and was leaning back with drooping eyelids.  /newquote  he said, languidly.
dialogue: Is she? /newquote I did not observe.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You really are an automaton, a calculating-machine! /newquote There is something positively inhuman in you at times.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is of the first importance, /newquote not to allow your judgment to be biased by personal qualities. A client is to me a mere unit, a factor in a problem. The emotional qualities are antagonistic to clear reasoning. I assure you that the most winning woman I ever knew was hanged for poisoning three little children for their insurance-money, and the most repellant man of my acquaintance is a philanthropist who has spent nearly a quarter of a million upon the London poor.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: In this case, however
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I never make exceptions. An exception disproves the rule. Have you ever had occasion to study character in handwriting? What do you make of this fellow s scribble?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is legible and regular, /newquote A man of business habits and some force of character.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: Holmes shook his head.  /newquote  he said.
dialogue: Look at his long letters, /newquote They hardly rise above the common herd. That _d_ might be an _a_, and that _l_ an _e_. Men of character always differentiate their long letters, however illegibly they may write. There is vacillation in his _k_ s and self-esteem in his capitals. I am going out now. I have some few references to make. Let me recommend this book, one of the most remarkable ever penned. It is Winwood Reade s  Martyrdom of Man.  I shall be back in an hour.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he said, taking the cup of tea which I had poured out for him.
dialogue: There is no great mystery in this matter, /newquote The facts appear to admit of only one explanation.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What! you have solved it already?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, that would be too much to say. I have discovered a suggestive fact, that is all. It is, however, _very_ suggestive. The details are still to be added. I have just found, on consulting the back files of the _Times_, that Major Sholto, of Upper Norword, late of the 34th Bombay Infantry, died upon the 28th of April, 1882.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I may be very obtuse, Holmes, but I fail to see what this suggests.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No? You surprise me. Look at it in this way, then. Captain Morstan disappears. The only person in London whom he could have visited is Major Sholto. Major Sholto denies having heard that he was in London. Four years later Sholto dies. _Within a week of his death_ Captain Morstan s daughter receives a valuable present, which is repeated from year to year, and now culminates in a letter which describes her as a wronged woman. What wrong can it refer to except this deprivation of her father? And why should the presents begin immediately after Sholto s death, unless it is that Sholto s heir knows something of the mystery and desires to make compensation? Have you any alternative theory which will meet the facts?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But what a strange compensation! And how strangely made! Why, too, should he write a letter now, rather than six years ago? Again, the letter speaks of giving her justice. What justice can she have? It is too much to suppose that her father is still alive. There is no other injustice in her case that you know of.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: There are difficulties; there are certainly difficulties, /newquote But our expedition of to-night will solve them all. Ah, here is a four-wheeler, and Miss Morstan is inside. Are you all ready? Then we had better go down, for it is a little past the hour.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: We heard her reiterated rejoicings until the door was closed and her voice died away into a muffled monotone.
dialogue: Oh, Mr. Thaddeus, sir, I am so glad you have come! I am so glad you have come, Mr. Thaddeus, sir!
speaker: Mrs. Bernstone
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Now, Watson, /newquote we have half an hour to ourselves. Let us make good use of it. My case is, as I have told you, almost complete; but we must not err on the side of over-confidence. Simple as the case seems now, there may be something deeper underlying it.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Simple!
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said he, with something of the air of a clinical professor expounding to his class.  /newquote  He carried the lamp across to it, muttering his observations aloud the while, but addressing them to himself rather than to me.
dialogue: Surely, /newquote Just sit in the corner there, that your footprints may not complicate matters. Now to work! In the first place, how did these folk come, and how did they go? The door has not been opened since last night. How of the window? /newquote Window is snibbed on the inner side. Framework is solid. No hinges at the side. Let us open it. No water-pipe near. Roof quite out of reach. Yet a man has mounted by the window. It rained a little last night. Here is the print of a foot in mould upon the sill. And here is a circular muddy mark, and here again upon the floor, and here again by the table. See here, Watson! This is really a very pretty demonstration.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I looked at the round, well-defined muddy discs.  /newquote  said I.
dialogue: This is not a footmark,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is something much more valuable to us. It is the impression of a wooden stump. You see here on the sill is the boot-mark, a heavy boot with the broad metal heel, and beside it is the mark of the timber-toe.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is the wooden-legged man.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Quite so. But there has been some one else, a very able and efficient ally. Could you scale that wall, doctor?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is absolutely impossible,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Without aid it is so. But suppose you had a friend up here who lowered you this good stout rope which I see in the corner, securing one end of it to this great hook in the wall. Then, I think, if you were an active man, You might swarm up, wooden leg and all. You would depart, of course, in the same fashion, and your ally would draw up the rope, untie it from the hook, shut the window, snib it on the inside, and get away in the way that he originally came. As a minor point it may be noted, /newquote that our wooden-legged friend, though a fair climber, was not a professional sailor. His hands were far from horny. My lens discloses more than one blood-mark, especially towards the end of the rope, from which I gather that he slipped down with such velocity that he took the skin off his hand.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: This is all very well, /newquote but the thing becomes more unintelligible than ever. How about this mysterious ally? How came he into the room?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, the ally! /newquote There are features of interest about this ally. He lifts the case from the regions of the commonplace. I fancy that this ally breaks fresh ground in the annals of crime in this country, though parallel cases suggest themselves from India, and, if my memory serves me, from Senegambia.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: How came he, then? /newquote The door is locked, the window is inaccessible. Was it through the chimney?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The grate is much too small, /newquote I had already considered that possibility.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: How then?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You will not apply my precept, /newquote How often have I said to you that when you have eliminated the impossible whatever remains, _however improbable_, must be the truth? We know that he did not come through the door, the window, or the chimney. We also know that he could not have been concealed in the room, as there is no concealment possible. Whence, then, did he come?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: He came through the hole in the roof,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Of course he did. He must have done so. If you will have the kindness to hold the lamp for me, we shall now extend our researches to the room above, the secret room in which the treasure was found.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Sherlock Holmes, putting his hand against the sloping wall.
dialogue: Here you are, you see, /newquote This is a trap-door which leads out on to the roof. I can press it back, and here is the roof itself, sloping at a gentle angle. This, then, is the way by which Number One entered. Let us see if we can find any other traces of his individuality.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Holmes, /newquote a child has done the horrid thing.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He had recovered his self-possession in an instant.  /newquote  he said,

append: said he, with a touch of impatience.
dialogue: My dear Watson, try a little analysis yourself, /newquote You know my methods. Apply them, and it will be instructive to compare results.

dialogue: I cannot conceive anything which will cover the facts,

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he said, in an off-hand way.  /newquote  He whipped out his lens and a tape measure, and hurried about the room on his knees, measuring, comparing, examining, with his long thin nose only a few inches from the planks, and his beady eyes gleaming and deep-set like those of a bird. So swift, silent, and furtive were his movements, like those of a trained blood-hound picking out a scent, that I could not but think what a terrible criminal he would have made had he turned his energy and sagacity against the law, instead of exerting them in its defence. As he hunted about, he kept muttering to himself, and finally he broke out into a loud crow of delight.
dialogue: It will be clear enough to you soon, /newquote I think that there is nothing else of importance here, but I will look.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: We are certainly in luck, /newquote We ought to have very little trouble now. Number One has had the misfortune to tread in the creosote. You can see the outline of the edge of his small foot here at the side of this evil-smelling mess. The carboy has been cracked, You see, and the stuff has leaked out.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What then?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Why, we have got him, that s all, /newquote I know a dog that would follow that scent to the world s end. If a pack can track a trailed herring across a shire, how far can a specially-trained hound follow so pungent a smell as this? It sounds like a sum in the rule of three. The answer should give us the But halloa! here are the accredited representatives of the law.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Before they come, /newquote just put your hand here on this poor fellow s arm, and here on his leg. What do you feel?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The muscles are as hard as a board,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Quite so. They are in a state of extreme contraction, far exceeding the usual _rigor mortis_. Coupled with this distortion of the face, this Hippocratic smile, or  _risus sardonicus_,  as the old writers called it, what conclusion would it suggest to your mind?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Death from some powerful vegetable alkaloid, /newquote some strychnine-like substance which would produce tetanus.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: That was the idea which occurred to me the instant I saw the drawn muscles of the face. On getting into the room I at once looked for the means by which the poison had entered the system. As you saw, I discovered a thorn which had been driven or shot with no great force into the scalp. You observe that the part struck was that which would be turned towards the hole in the ceiling if the man were erect in his chair. Now examine the thorn.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Is that an English thorn?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, it certainly is not.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: With all these data you should be able to draw some just inference. But here are the regulars; so the auxiliary forces may beat a retreat.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: He can find something, /newquote He has occasional glimmerings of reason. _Il n y a pas des sots si incommodes que ceux qui ont de l esprit!_

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He led me out to the head of the stair.  /newquote  he said,
dialogue: This unexpected occurrence, /newquote has caused us rather to lose sight of the original purpose of our journey.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I have just been thinking so, /newquote It is not right that Miss Morstan should remain in this stricken house.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No. You must escort her home. She lives with Mrs. Cecil Forrester, in Lower Camberwell: so it is not very far. I will wait for you here if you will drive out again. Or perhaps you are too tired?

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: By no means. I don t think I could rest until I know more of this fantastic business. I have seen something of the rough side of life, but I give you my word that this quick succession of strange surprises to-night has shaken my nerve completely. I should like, however, to see the matter through with you, now that I have got so far.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Your presence will be of great service to me, /newquote We shall work the case out independently, and leave this fellow Jones to exult over any mare s-nest which he may choose to construct. When you have dropped Miss Morstan I wish you to go on to No. 3, Pinchin Lane, down near the water s edge at Lambeth. The third house on the right-hand side is a bird-stuffer s: Sherman is the name. You will see a weasel holding a young rabbit in the window. Knock old Sherman up, and tell him, with my compliments, that I want Toby at once. You will bring Toby back in the cab with you.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: A dog, I suppose.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, a queer mongrel, with a most amazing power of scent. I would rather have Toby s help than that of the whole detective force of London.

Ah, naughty, naughty, would you take a nip at the gentleman? /newquote Don t mind that, sir: it s only a slow-worm. It hain t got no fangs, so I gives it the run o  the room, for it keeps the beetles down. You must not mind my bein  just a little short wi  you at first, for I m guyed at by the children, and there s many a one just comes down this lane to knock me up. append: He moved slowly forward with his candle among the queer animal family which he had gathered round him. In the uncertain, shadowy light I could see dimly that there were glancing, glimmering eyes peeping down at us from every cranny and corner. Even the rafters above our heads were lined by solemn fowls, who lazily shifted their weight from one leg to the other as our voices disturbed their slumbers.
dialogue: Toby lives at No. 7 on the left here.
speaker: Mr. Sherman
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Ah, you have him there! /newquote Good dog, then! Atheney Jones has gone. We have had an immense display of energy since you left. He has arrested not only friend Thaddeus, but the gatekeeper, the housekeeper, and the Indian servant. We have the place to ourselves, but for a sergeant upstairs. Leave the dog here, and come up.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I wish you particularly to notice these footmarks, /newquote Do you observe anything noteworthy about them?

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: They belong, /newquote to a child or a small woman.

dialogue: Apart from their size, though. Is there nothing else?

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: They appear to be much as other footmarks.

dialogue: Not at all. Look here! This is the print of a right foot in the dust. Now I make one with my naked foot beside it. What is the chief difference?

dialogue: Quite so. That is the point. Bear that in mind. Now, would you kindly step over to that flap-window and smell the edge of the wood-work? I shall stay here, as I have this handkerchief in my hand.

speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes

append: He pushed the creasote handkerchief under the dog s nose, while the creature stood with its fluffy legs separated, and with a most comical cock to its head, like a connoisseur sniffing the _bouquet_ of a famous vintage. Holmes then threw the handkerchief to a distance, fastened a stout cord to the mongrel s collar, and led him to the foot of the water-barrel. The creature instantly broke into a succession of high, tremulous yelps, and, with his nose on the ground, and his tail in the air, pattered off upon the trail at a pace which strained his leash and kept us at the top of our speed.
dialogue: Here you are, doggy! Good old Toby! Smell it, Toby, smell it!
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: he remarked, as I mounted up beside him.
dialogue: There s the print of wooden-leg s hand, /newquote You see the slight smudge of blood upon the white plaster. What a lucky thing it is that we have had no very heavy rain since yesterday! The scent will lie upon the road in spite of their eight-and-twenty hours  start.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Do not imagine, /newquote that I depend for my success in this case upon the mere chance of one of these fellows having put his foot in the chemical. I have knowledge now which would enable me to trace them in many different ways. This, however, is the readiest and, since fortune has put it into our hands, I should be culpable if I neglected it. It has, however, prevented the case from becoming the pretty little intellectual problem which it at one time promised to be. There might have been some credit to be gained out of it, but for this too palpable clue.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: There is credit, and to spare, /newquote I assure you, Holmes, that I marvel at the means by which you obtain your results in this case, even more than I did in the Jefferson Hope Murder. The thing seems to me to be deeper and more inexplicable. How, for example, could you describe with such confidence the wooden-legged man?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Pshaw, my dear boy! it was simplicity itself. I don t wish to be theatrical. It is all patent and above-board. Two officers who are in command of a convict-guard learn an important secret as to buried treasure. A map is drawn for them by an Englishman named Jonathan Small. You remember that we saw the name upon the chart in Captain Morstan s possession. He had signed it in behalf of himself and his associates, the sign of the four, as he somewhat dramatically called it. Aided by this chart, the officers or one of them gets the treasure and brings it to England, leaving, we will suppose, some condition under which he received it unfulfilled. Now, then, why did not Jonathan Small get the treasure himself? The answer is obvious. The chart is dated at a time when Morstan was brought into close association with convicts. Jonathan Small did not get the treasure because he and his associates were themselves convicts and could not get away.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But that is mere speculation,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: It is more than that. It is the only hypothesis which covers the facts. Let us see how it fits in with the sequel. Major Sholto remains at peace for some years, happy in the possession of his treasure. Then he receives a letter from India which gives him a great fright. What was that?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: A letter to say that the men whom he had wronged had been set free.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Or had escaped. That is much more likely, for he would have known what their term of imprisonment was. It would not have been a surprise to him. What does he do then? He guards himself against a wooden-legged man, a white man, mark you, for he mistakes a white tradesman for him, and actually fires a pistol at him. Now, only one white man s name is on the chart. The others are Hindoos or Mohammedans. There is no other white man. Therefore we may say with confidence that the wooden-legged man is identical with Jonathan Small. Does the reasoning strike you as being faulty?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No: it is clear and concise.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, now, let us put ourselves in the place of Jonathan Small. Let us look at it from his point of view. He comes to England with the double idea of regaining what he would consider to be his rights and of having his revenge upon the man who had wronged him. He found out where Sholto lived, and very possibly he established communications with some one inside the house. There is this butler, Lal Rao, whom we have not seen. Mrs. Bernstone gives him far from a good character. Small could not find out, however, where the treasure was hid, for no one ever knew, save the major and one faithful servant who had died. Suddenly Small learns that the major is on his death-bed. In a frenzy lest the secret of the treasure die with him, he runs the gauntlet of the guards, makes his way to the dying man s window, and is only deterred from entering by the presence of his two sons. Mad with hate, however, against the dead man, he enters the room that night, searches his private papers in the hope of discovering some memorandum relating to the treasure, and finally leaves a momento of his visit in the short inscription upon the card. He had doubtless planned beforehand that should he slay the major he would leave some such record upon the body as a sign that it was not a common murder, but, from the point of view of the four associates, something in the nature of an act of justice. Whimsical and bizarre conceits of this kind are common enough in the annals of crime, and usually afford valuable indications as to the criminal. Do you follow all this?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Very clearly.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Now, what could Jonathan Small do? He could only continue to keep a secret watch upon the efforts made to find the treasure. Possibly he leaves England and only comes back at intervals. Then comes the discovery of the garret, and he is instantly informed of it. We again trace the presence of some confederate in the household. Jonathan, with his wooden leg, is utterly unable to reach the lofty room of Bartholomew Sholto. He takes with him, however, a rather curious associate, who gets over this difficulty, but dips his naked foot into creasote, whence comes Toby, and a six-mile limp for a half-pay officer with a damaged tendo Achillis.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But it was the associate, and not Jonathan, who committed the crime.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Quite so. And rather to Jonathan s disgust, to judge by the way he stamped about when he got into the room. He bore no grudge against Bartholomew Sholto, and would have preferred if he could have been simply bound and gagged. He did not wish to put his head in a halter. There was no help for it, however: the savage instincts of his companion had broken out, and the poison had done its work: so Jonathan Small left his record, lowered the treasure-box to the ground, and followed it himself. That was the train of events as far as I can decipher them. Of course as to his personal appearance he must be middle-aged, and must be sunburned after serving his time in such an oven as the Andamans. His height is readily calculated from the length of his stride, and we know that he was bearded. His hairiness was the one point which impressed itself upon Thaddeus Sholto when he saw him at the window. I don t know that there is anything else.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The associate?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Ah, well, there is no great mystery in that. But you will know all about it soon enough. How sweet the morning air is! See how that one little cloud floats like a pink feather from some gigantic flamingo. Now the red rim of the sun pushes itself over the London cloud-bank. It shines on a good many folk, but on none, I dare bet, who are on a stranger errand than you and I. How small we feel with our petty ambitions and strivings in the presence of the great elemental forces of nature! Are you well up in your Jean Paul?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Fairly so. I worked back to him through Carlyle.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: That was like following the brook to the parent lake. He makes one curious but profound remark. It is that the chief proof of man s real greatness lies in his perception of his own smallness. It argues, you see, a power of comparison and of appreciation which is in itself a proof of nobility. There is much food for thought in Richter. You have not a pistol, have you?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I have my stick.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He took out his revolver as he spoke, and, having loaded two of the chambers, he put it back into the right-hand pocket of his jacket.
dialogue: It is just possible that we may need something of the sort if we get to their lair. Jonathan I shall leave to you, but if the other turns nasty I shall shoot him dead.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What the deuce is the matter with the dog? /newquote They surely would not take a cab, or go off in a balloon.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes

dialogue: Perhaps they stood here for some time,

speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: We must get on the main scent again, I suppose.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes. And, fortunately, we have no distance to go. Evidently what puzzled the dog at the corner of Knight s Place was that there were two different trails running in opposite directions. We took the wrong one. It only remains to follow the other.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: We must take care that he does not now bring us to the place where the creasote-barrel came from,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I had thought of that. But you notice that he keeps on the pavement, whereas the barrel passed down the roadway. No, we are on the true scent now.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Holmes.  /newquote  Several small punts and skiffs were lying about in the water and on the edge of the wharf. We took Toby round to each in turn, but, though he sniffed earnestly, he made no sign.
dialogue: We are out of luck, /newquote They have taken to a boat here.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: This looks bad, /newquote These fellows are sharper than I expected. They seem to have covered their tracks. There has, I fear, been preconcerted management here.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Holmes, as we sat in the sheets of the wherry,
dialogue: The main thing with people of that sort, /newquote is never to let them think that their information can be of the slightest importance to you. If you do, they will instantly shut up like an oyster. If you listen to them under protest, as it were, you are very likely to get what you want.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Our course now seems pretty clear,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What would you do, then?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I would engage a launch and go down the river on the track of the _Aurora_.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: My dear fellow, it would be a colossal task. She may have touched at any wharf on either side of the stream between here and Greenwich. Below the bridge there is a perfect labyrinth of landing-places for miles. It would take you days and days to exhaust them, if you set about it alone.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Employ the police, then.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No. I shall probably call Athelney Jones in at the last moment. He is not a bad fellow, and I should not like to do anything which would injure him professionally. But I have a fancy for working it out myself, now that we have gone so far.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Could we advertise, then, asking for information from wharfingers?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Worse and worse! Our men would know that the chase was hot at their heels, and they would be off out of the country. As it is, they are likely enough to leave, but as long as they think they are perfectly safe they will be in no hurry. Jones s energy will be of use to us there, for his view of the case is sure to push itself into the daily press, and the runaways will think that every one is off on the wrong scent.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I asked, as we landed near Millbank Penitentiary.
dialogue: What are we to do, then?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Take this hansom, drive home, have some breakfast, and get an hour s sleep. It is quite on the cards that we may be afoot to-night again. Stop at a telegraph-office, cabby! We will keep Toby, for he may be of use to us yet.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: We pulled up at the Great Peter Street post-office, and Holmes despatched his wire.  /newquote  he asked, as we resumed our journey.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I am sure I don t know.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You remember the Baker Street division of the detective police force whom I employed in the Jefferson Hope case?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: This is just the case where they might be invaluable. If they fail, I have other resources; but I shall try them first. That wire was to my dirty little lieutenant, Wiggins, and I expect that he and his gang will be with us before we have finished our breakfast.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said he, laughing, and pointing to an open newspaper.
dialogue: Here it is, /newquote The energetic Jones and the ubiquitous reporter have fixed it up between them. But you have had enough of the case. Better have your ham and eggs first.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I think that we have had a close shave ourselves of being arrested for the crime.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: So do I. I wouldn t answer for our safety now, if he should happen to have another of his attacks of energy.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: By heaven, Holmes, /newquote I believe that they are really after us.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, it s not quite so bad as that. It is the unofficial force, the Baker Street irregulars.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Holmes, as he rose from the table and lit his pipe.
dialogue: If the launch is above water they will find her, /newquote They can go everywhere, see everything, overhear every one. I expect to hear before evening that they have spotted her. In the meanwhile, we can do nothing but await results. We cannot pick up the broken trail until we find either the _Aurora_ or Mr. Mordecai Smith.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Toby could eat these scraps, I dare say. Are you going to bed, Holmes?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No; I am not tired. I have a curious constitution. I never remember feeling tired by work, though idleness exhausts me completely. I am going to smoke and to think over this queer business to which my fair client has introduced us. If ever man had an easy task, this of ours ought to be. Wooden-legged men are not so common, but the other man must, I should think, be absolutely unique.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: That other man again!
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I have no wish to make a mystery of him, to you, anyway. But you must have formed your own opinion. Now, do consider the data. Diminutive footmarks, toes never fettered by boots, naked feet, stone-headed wooden mace, great agility, small poisoned darts. What do you make of all this?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: A savage! /newquote Perhaps one of those Indians who were the associates of Jonathan Small.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Hardly that, /newquote When first I saw signs of strange weapons I was inclined to think so; but the remarkable character of the footmarks caused me to reconsider my views. Some of the inhabitants of the Indian Peninsula are small men, but none could have left such marks as that. The Hindoo proper has long and thin feet. The sandal-wearing Mohammedan has the great toe well separated from the others, because the thong is commonly passed between. These little darts, too, could only be shot in one way. They are from a blow-pipe. Now, then, where are we to find our savage?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: South American,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: But how came he to have so singular a companion?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Ah, that is more than I can tell. Since, however, we had already determined that Small had come from the Andamans, it is not so very wonderful that this islander should be with him. No doubt we shall know all about it in time. Look here, Watson; you look regularly done. Lie down there on the sofa, and see if I can put you to sleep.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You have slept soundly, /newquote I feared that our talk would wake you.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I heard nothing, /newquote Have you had fresh news, then?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Unfortunately, no. I confess that I am surprised and disappointed. I expected something definite by this time. Wiggins has just been up to report. He says that no trace can be found of the launch. It is a provoking check, for every hour is of importance.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Can I do anything? I am perfectly fresh now, and quite ready for another night s outing.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, we can do nothing. We can only wait. If we go ourselves, the message might come in our absence, and delay be caused. You can do what you will, but I must remain on guard.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Then I shall run over to Camberwell and call upon Mrs. Cecil Forrester. She asked me to, yesterday.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, of course Miss Morstan too. They were anxious to hear what happened.

subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I would not tell them too much, /newquote Women are never to be entirely trusted, not the best of them.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: All right! Good luck! But, I say, if you are crossing the river you may as well return Toby, for I don t think it is at all likely that we shall have any use for him now.

speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, he s that strange, sir. After you was gone he walked and he walked, up and down, and up and down, until I was weary of the sound of his footstep. Then I heard him talking to himself and muttering, and every time the bell rang out he came on the stairhead, with  What is that, Mrs. Hudson?  And now he has slammed off to his room, but I can hear him walking away the same as ever. I hope he s not going to be ill, sir. I ventured to say something to him about cooling medicine, but he turned on me, sir, with such a look that I don t know how ever I got out of the room.
speaker: Mrs. Hudson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I answered.  /newquote  I tried to speak lightly to our worthy landlady, but I was myself somewhat uneasy when through the long night I still from time to time heard the dull sound of his tread, and knew how his keen spirit was chafing against this involuntary inaction.
dialogue: I don t think that you have any cause to be uneasy, Mrs. Hudson, /newquote I have seen him like this before. He has some small matter upon his mind which makes him restless.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You are knocking yourself up, old man, /newquote I heard you marching about in the night.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, I could not sleep, /newquote This infernal problem is consuming me. It is too much to be balked by so petty an obstacle, when all else had been overcome. I know the men, the launch, everything; and yet I can get no news. I have set other agencies at work, and used every means at my disposal. The whole river has been searched on either side, but there is no news, nor has Mrs. Smith heard of her husband. I shall come to the conclusion soon that they have scuttled the craft. But there are objections to that.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Or that Mrs. Smith has put us on a wrong scent.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, I think that may be dismissed. I had inquiries made, and there is a launch of that description.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Could it have gone up the river?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I have considered that possibility too, and there is a search-party who will work up as far as Richmond. If no news comes to-day, I shall start off myself to-morrow, and go for the men rather than the boat. But surely, surely, we shall hear something.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I am off down the river, Watson, /newquote I have been turning it over in my mind, and I can see only one way out of it. It is worth trying, at all events.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Surely I can come with you, then?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No; you can be much more useful if you will remain here as my representative. I am loath to go, for it is quite on the cards that some message may come during the day, though Wiggins was despondent about it last night. I want you to open all notes and telegrams, and to act on your own judgment if any news should come. Can I rely upon you?
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Most certainly.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I am afraid that you will not be able to wire to me, for I can hardly tell yet where I may find myself. If I am in luck, however, I may not be gone so very long. I shall have news of some sort or other before I get back.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Good-day, sir; good-day, /newquote Mr. Sherlock Holmes is out, I understand.
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, and I cannot be sure when he will be back. But perhaps you would care to wait. Take that chair and try one of these cigars.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said he, mopping his face with a red bandanna handkerchief.
dialogue: Thank you; I don t mind if I do,
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: And a whiskey-and-soda?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, half a glass. It is very hot for the time of year; and I have had a good deal to worry and try me. You know my theory about this Norwood case?
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I remember that you expressed one.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Well, I have been obliged to reconsider it. I had my net drawn tightly round Mr. Sholto, sir, when pop he went through a hole in the middle of it. He was able to prove an alibi which could not be shaken. From the time that he left his brother s room he was never out of sight of some one or other. So it could not be he who climbed over roofs and through trap-doors. It s a very dark case, and my professional credit is at stake. I should be very glad of a little assistance.
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: We all need help sometimes,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said he, in a husky and confidential voice.
dialogue: Your friend Mr. Sherlock Holmes is a wonderful man, sir, /newquote He s a man who is not to be beat. I have known that young man go into a good many cases, but I never saw the case yet that he could not throw a light upon. He is irregular in his methods, and a little quick perhaps in jumping at theories, but, on the whole, I think he would have made a most promising officer, and I don t care who knows it. I have had a wire from him this morning, by which I understand that he has got some clue to this Sholto business. Here is the message.
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: This sounds well. He has evidently picked up the scent again,
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Ah, then he has been at fault too, /newquote Even the best of us are thrown off sometimes. Of course this may prove to be a false alarm; but it is my duty as an officer of the law to allow no chance to slip. But there is some one at the door. Perhaps this is he.
speaker: Mr. Athelney Jones
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I heard a cab drive up, /newquote I thought that Mrs. Forrester had come back very early, but I never dreamed that it might be you. What news have you brought me?
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said I, putting down the box upon the table and speaking jovially and boisterously, though my heart was heavy within me.
dialogue: I have brought something better than news, /newquote I have brought you something which is worth all the news in the world. I have brought you a fortune.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She glanced at the iron box.  /newquote  she asked, coolly enough.
dialogue: Is that the treasure, then?
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, this is the great Agra treasure. Half of it is yours and half is Thaddeus Sholto s. You will have a couple of hundred thousand each. Think of that! An annuity of ten thousand pounds. There will be few richer young ladies in England. Is it not glorious?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: If I have it, /newquote I owe it to you.
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: No, no, /newquote not to me, but to my friend Sherlock Holmes. With all the will in the world, I could never have followed up a clue which has taxed even his analytical genius. As it was, we very nearly lost it at the last moment.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Pray sit down and tell me all about it, Dr. Watson,
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she said, as I hastened to pour her out some water.
dialogue: It is nothing, /newquote I am all right again. It was a shock to me to hear that I had placed my friends in such horrible peril.
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: That is all over, /newquote It was nothing. I will tell you no more gloomy details. Let us turn to something brighter. There is the treasure. What could be brighter than that? I got leave to bring it with me, thinking that it would interest you to be the first to see it.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she said. There was no eagerness in her voice, however. It had struck her, doubtless, that it might seem ungracious upon her part to be indifferent to a prize which had cost so much to win.
dialogue: It would be of the greatest interest to me,
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What a pretty box! /newquote This is Indian work, I suppose?
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes; it is Benares metal-work.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she exclaimed, trying to raise it.
dialogue: And so heavy! /newquote The box alone must be of some value. Where is the key?
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I answered.  /newquote  There was in the front a thick and broad hasp, wrought in the image of a sitting Buddha. Under this I thrust the end of the poker and twisted it outward as a lever. The hasp sprang open with a loud snap. With trembling fingers I flung back the lid. We both stood gazing in astonishment. The box was empty!
dialogue: Small threw it into the Thames, /newquote I must borrow Mrs. Forrester s poker.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The treasure is lost,
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: As I listened to the words and realised what they meant, a great shadow seemed to pass from my soul. I did not know how this Agra treasure had weighed me down, until now that it was finally removed. It was selfish, no doubt, disloyal, wrong, but I could realise nothing save that the golden barrier was gone from between us.  /newquote  I ejaculated from my very heart.
dialogue: Thank God!
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: She looked at me with a quick, questioning smile.  /newquote  she asked.
dialogue: Why do you say that?
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I said, taking her hand. She did not withdraw it.
dialogue: Because you are within my reach again, /newquote Because I love you, Mary, as truly as ever a man loved a woman. Because this treasure, these riches, sealed my lips. Now that they are gone I can tell you how I love you. That is why I said,  Thank God.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: she whispered, as I drew her to my side. Whoever had lost a treasure, I knew that night that I had gained one.
dialogue: Then I say,  Thank God,  too,
speaker: Miss Morstan
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: There goes the reward! /newquote Where there is no money there is no pay. This night s work would have been worth a tenner each to Sam Brown and me if the treasure had been there.
speaker: A Bluff, Genial Inspector
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Mr. Thaddeus Sholto is a rich man, /newquote He will see that you are rewarded, treasure or no.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: The inspector shook his head despondently, however.  /newquote  he repeated;
dialogue: It s a bad job, /newquote and so Mr. Athelney Jones will think.
speaker: A Bluff, Genial Inspector
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I will swear it,  I answered,  provided that the fort is not endangered.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: There are but three,  said I.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Does your brother know, then, of what you will do?  I asked.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The plan is his. He has devised it. We will go to the gate and share the watch with Mahomet Singh.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You will challenge him, Sahib, as usual,  whispered Abdullah.  Give him no cause for fear. Send us in with him, and we shall do the rest while you stay here on guard. Have the lantern ready to uncover, that we may be sure that it is indeed the man.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: What have you in the bundle?  I asked.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I wish to have your advice, major,  said I.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Quite that, sir, in jewels and pearls. It lies there ready for any one. And the queer thing about it is that the real owner is outlawed and cannot hold property, so that it belongs to the first comer.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: You think, then, sir, that I should give the information to the Governor-General?  said I, quietly.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I remarked, after we had set some time smoking in silence.
dialogue: Well, and there is the end of our little drama, /newquote I fear that it may be the last investigation in which I shall have the chance of studying your methods. Miss Morstan has done me the honour to accept me as a husband in prospective.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: He gave a most dismal groan.  /newquote  said he.
dialogue: I feared as much, /newquote I really cannot congratulate you.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: I was a little hurt.  /newquote  I asked.
dialogue: Have you any reason to be dissatisfied with my choice?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Not at all. I think she is one of the most charming young ladies I ever met, and might have been most useful in such work as we have been doing. She had a decided genius that way: witness the way in which she preserved that Agra plan from all the other papers of her father. But love is an emotional thing, and whatever is emotional is opposed to that true cold reason which I place above all things. I should never marry myself, lest I bias my judgment.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: I trust, /newquote that my judgment may survive the ordeal. But you look weary.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, the reaction is already upon me. I shall be as limp as a rag for a week.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Strange, /newquote how terms of what in another man I should call laziness alternate with your fits of splendid energy and vigour.
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: Yes, /newquote there are in me the makings of a very fine loafer and also of a pretty spry sort of fellow. I often think of those lines of old Goethe,
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: By the way, _  propos_ of this Norwood business, you see that they had, as I surmised, a confederate in the house, who could be none other than Lal Rao, the butler: so Jones actually has the undivided honour of having caught one fish in his great haul.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

dialogue: The division seems rather unfair, /newquote You have done all the work in this business. I get a wife out of it, Jones gets the credit, pray what remains for you?
speaker: Dr. Watson
subject: NO MONOLOGUE

append: said Sherlock Holmes,  /newquote  And he stretched his long white hand up for it.
dialogue: For me, /newquote there still remains the cocaine-bottle.
speaker: Mr. Sherlock Holmes
subject: NO MONOLOGUE
